Show all your work. Indicate clearly the methods you use, because you will be scored on the correctness of your methods as well as on the accuracy and completeness of your results and explanations.

The principal at a large high school believes that the amount of sleep that the <math alttext="2,500" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn><mtext>,500</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> students at the school get, on average, per day is different from eight hours. A random sample of <math alttext="100" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>100</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> students from the school were surveyed with the following question.

How many hours of sleep do you usually get per day?

From the <math alttext="100" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>100</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> respondents, the principal obtained a one-sample <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-interval to estimate <math alttext="mu sub S" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>μ</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>S</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, the mean amount of sleep, in hours, that all students at the school get per day. Assume the conditions for inference have been met. At the <math alttext="90" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>90</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> percent confidence level, the interval was <math alttext="7.821 plus or minus 0.270" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>7.821</mn><mo>±</mo><mn>0.270</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(a) Does the confidence interval support the principal’s belief that the amount of sleep that all students at the school get, on average, per day is different from eight hours? Justify your answer.

A random sample of <math alttext="100" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>100</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> students from the school were surveyed with the following question.

How many hours of sleep do you usually get per day?

From the <math alttext="100" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>100</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> respondents, the principal obtained a one-sample <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-interval to estimate <math alttext="mu sub S" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>μ</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>S</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, the mean amount of sleep, in hours, that all students at the school get per day. Assume the conditions for inference have been met. At the <math alttext="90" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>90</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> percent confidence level, the interval was <math alttext="7.821 plus or minus 0.270" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>7.821</mn><mo>±</mo><mn>0.270</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(a) Does the confidence interval support the principal’s belief that the amount of sleep that all students at the school get, on average, per day is different from eight hours? Justify your answer.

Upon further investigation, the principal believes that underclassmen (freshmen and sophomores) may respond differently to the survey than upperclassmen (juniors and seniors). The principal plans to conduct a new survey using independent random samples of underclassmen and upperclassmen. Assume that there are approximately equal numbers of underclassman and upperclassmen at the school.
(b) Describe a method that the principal could use to obtain two independent random samples, one of <math alttext="20" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>20</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> underclassmen and one of <math alttext="19" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>19</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> upperclassmen, from the <math alttext="2,500" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn><mtext>,</mtext><mn>500</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> students at the school.

(c) The principal wants to use an inference procedure to investigate whether the sample data provide convincing statistical evidence of a difference in the population mean amounts of sleep, in hours, that underclassmen and upperclassmen would get per day. Explain whether each condition for inference is met.

The principal decided to also ask each student in the new survey to report the amount of extracurricular activities, in hours, they participate in per week. The scatterplot below shows the data for each of the students in the two samples.

(d) Describe what the scatterplot reveals about the relationship between amount of extracurricular activities per week and amount of sleep per day for each of the following: the <math alttext="20" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>20</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> underclassmen and the <math alttext="19" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>19</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> upperclassmen.

A scatterplot of only the <math alttext="19" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>19</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> upperclassmen is shown, along with regression output for a linear model using amount of extracurricular activities per week to predict amount of sleep per day.

The circled point on the scatterplot represents a student who reported <math alttext="30" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>30</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> hours of extracurricular activities per week and <math alttext="9.75" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>9.75</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> hours of sleep per day.

(e) Describe the impact on the slope of the least-squares regression line and the coefficient of determination, <math alttext="r squared" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>r</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>, if the circled point was removed from the data. Explain your answer.

skill.text: Skill 1.C: Describe an appropriate method for gathering and representing data.
